category_summary:
The **OpenAI-Musk dispute** dominated AI discourse as **Greg Brockman** broke years of silence with documentary evidence, [accusing Elon of 'beyond dishonest' cherry-picking](/?date=2026-01-18&category=social#item-5dd78602c5d6) from his personal journal. Brockman revealed Elon demanded majority equity and total control, wanting to accumulate $80B through OpenAI‚Äîclaims backed by deposition links.

- **Google's Logan Kilpatrick** [announced free access](/?date=2026-01-18&category=social#item-b79a1476357c) to **Gemini 3 Flash and Pro** in AI Studio, while also hiring interns across product and vibe coding roles
- **Anthropic** [shipped a significant **Claude Code** update](/?date=2026-01-18&category=social#item-dfe4acb2e84b): plans now auto-clear context for fresh execution windows
- **HuggingFace CEO Clem Delangue** [promoted local model deployment](/?date=2026-01-18&category=social#item-81ff54f5b4b4) for privacy (329K views), signaling growing enterprise concern about cloud data
- **MIT CSAIL** [shared that **ChatGPT**](/?date=2026-01-18&category=social#item-c1141a2d3b55) now ranks as the 4th most visited website globally, surpassing Instagram

Developer tooling discussions featured **Jerry Liu** [demoing AI form-filling agents](/?date=2026-01-18&category=social#item-bafa79dcade9) with Claude Agent SDK, while **Burkov** sparked debate [arguing 'coding is solved'](/?date=2026-01-18&category=social#item-8abc81070d79) due to its deterministic nature‚Äîcontrasting with messy human work where AGI would struggle.
category_summary_html:
The OpenAI-Musk dispute dominated AI discourse as Greg Brockman broke years of silence with documentary evidence, accusing Elon of 'beyond dishonest' cherry-picking from his personal journal. Brockman revealed Elon demanded majority equity and total control, wanting to accumulate $80B through OpenAI‚Äîclaims backed by deposition links.

  • Google's Logan Kilpatrick announced free access to Gemini 3 Flash and Pro in AI Studio, while also hiring interns across product and vibe coding roles
  • Anthropic shipped a significant Claude Code update: plans now auto-clear context for fresh execution windows
  • HuggingFace CEO Clem Delangue promoted local model deployment for privacy (329K views), signaling growing enterprise concern about cloud data

Looking forward to finally having an opportunity to talk about the real history of OpenAI.

items.title: The negotiations touched on personal motivations, e.g. Elon told us he wanted OpenAI equity in order...
items.content:
The negotiations touched on personal motivations, e.g. Elon told us he wanted OpenAI equity in order to accumulate $80B.

I spent a lot of thought on what could be my own motivations, with my personal journal reading like a long "chain of thought". My deposition has some additional context which may be helpful: https://t.co/Kg8Jv3Jluh.

As a product of this reflection, Ilya and I realized we couldn't give Elon unilateral control, which we decided was against the mission. That was unacceptable to him. Prior to this, Elon was committed enough to the for-profit idea that he actually created the "Open Artificial Intelligence Technologies" for-profit:

items.title: Now in Claude Code: when you accept a plan, Claude automatically clears your context, so your plan g...
items.content:
Now in Claude Code: when you accept a plan, Claude automatically clears your context, so your plan gets a fresh context window.

We found this helps keep Claude on track longer, and significantly improves plan adherence.

If you prefer not to clear your context when accepting a plan, that option is still available too.

items.title: Coding was solved because coding is a deterministic task (code either works or doesn't work) and bec...
items.content:
Coding was solved because coding is a deterministic task (code either works or doesn't work) and because of how simple it is to define the reward for reinforcement learning: 1 when code produces the expected output (a simple string match is enough) and less than 1 otherwise.

If it were as simple to assign rewards for everything we do in life, the AGI would already be built.

But ~90% of what we need our brain for is guessing under a messy uncertainty, solutions can be many, and the rewards are based on chemistry different for different people.

Luckily for coders, they've had about 3 decades of lucrative job market where people capable of thinking like computers were rare.
items.author: @burkov
items.summary: Burkov argues 'coding is solved' due to determinism and simple reward signals; most human work involves messy uncertainty where AGI would struggle
items.reasoning: Provocative and substantive claim with technical reasoning, very high engagement (67K views), sparks important debate

items.title:
You shouldn't be waiting for someone to publish a new set of AI Engineering best practices.

You wil...
items.content:
You shouldn't be waiting for someone to publish a new set of AI Engineering best practices.

You will learn more from one weekend building a broken app than from six months of reading "How to Build with AI" posts.

The people who are trying things, failing, finding workarounds, and shipping rough prototypes are the ones who will be writing the best practices.

items.title:
If I was Elon Musk, I would never sell the CyberCab or the Optimus robot. 

I would force everybody ...
items.content:
If I was Elon Musk, I would never sell the CyberCab or the Optimus robot. 

I would force everybody to rent it, either by the mile, the hour, or the week.

That way, you can optimize the use of these things for the goals of Tesla, which is still to bring us into a sustainable, abundant world.

For the last eight years, I've been a Silicon Valley housewife doing a lot of laundry, washing dishes, and a little bit of cooking. The truth is, it's going to be hard for the typical American family to afford one of these robots in their homes. However, if you could rent one to do your laundry, it would be much more affordable. A $100,000 robot could be rented to you for around $20 an hour, while the wholesale cost of operation would only be about $4 or $5 an hour.

Maintenance issues (such as broken hands, worn-out batteries, or actuators that need replacing) would be covered by the rental fee. This model also allows the government or Tesla to adjust prices based on regulation. Eventually, we may see robots regulated to help pay for everyone's housing and food. If you sell the robots outright, it's difficult to recoup costs from new regulations, but if you rent them, you can simply increase the price to cover those costs as they arise.

A rental model offers several advantages:
1. Resource Sharing: A single robot could be shared among neighbors or different businesses. A company might only need a robot for eight hours a day to perform a specific job; after that, it could be returned to the network to work as a security guard overnight.
2. Maximized Utility: This ensures each individual robot is used to its full potential, preventing wealthy individuals from buying them up just to let them sit idle in a garage or only use them for parties.
3. Continual Revenue: This would provide Tesla with a steady revenue stream, which investors prefer.

Tesla seems to be signaling this shift already by moving away from selling Full Self-Driving (FSD) outright. Starting in February, they are reportedly only renting the software for $100 a month. We are heading into a world where everything is rented based on your immediate needs, and I wouldn't be shocked if this is the path Elon Musk takes going forward.

The big question for the CyberCab is:
(a) Does Elon want customers to fund the financing of the Robotaxi network so he doesn't have to put up as much money upfront?
(b) Or does he want to own all the revenues from the network himself?

I can see why he would want all of it. If I were Tesla or Elon, that's exactly how I would be looking at the world. How about you?

By the way, I'm on Highway 101 in the fast lane, following two Teslas and writing this by talking to Typeless (which I love) and using my voice to write these posts. 

If you're in an autonomous car, get a good voice system. I like Typeless, but there are others that are really good too‚Äîjust make sure you get one of them!

items.title: Here is the thing: I know of many, many, many super intelligent, curious, high-agency people who wou...
items.content: Here is the thing: I know of many, many, many super intelligent, curious, high-agency people who would still not be able to create such apps. The biggest barrier right now is the mindset. People who have been writing code and building apps for most of their professional life still grossly underestimate how "weird" and counterintuitive that work is, even for most people in highly cognitively loaded professions.
items.author: @tunguz
items.summary: Key insight: The biggest barrier to AI app creation is mindset, not intelligence. Many smart people still can't build apps because they underestimate how counterintuitive coding is

items.summary_html: Key insight: The biggest barrier to AI app creation is mindset, not intelligence. Many smart people still can't build apps because they underestimate how counterintuitive coding is
items.content_html: Here is the thing: I know of many, many, many super intelligent, curious, high-agency people who would still not be able to create such apps. The biggest barrier right now is the mindset. People who have been writing code and building apps for most of their professional life still grossly underestimate how "weird" and counterintuitive that work is, even for most people in highly cognitively loaded professions.

items.title:
The world model builder, or the guy who is keeping America competitive with China in robotics AI.

M...
items.content:
The world model builder, or the guy who is keeping America competitive with China in robotics AI.

Most people don't know @bercankilic but you should.

Almost every robotics company in San Francisco/Silicon Valley buys his data. Video data. He is largely seen as the best at providing that data in the world.

Yesterday I got to know him a lot better. Took him and his cofounders to Bucks Restaurant after visiting @tangiblerobots with him and meeting with its CEO @bipashasen31. Who just moved into their new office, investor @Shaughnessy119 visited right before me and praised the team there: https://t.co/OzaQmRWHBD

Aside: when you walk into Tangible Robotics headquarters they have a full bedroom right in front of their headquarters where they train their robot to do things like folding laundry, making beds, cleaning up and organizing. All tasks we will want our robots to do someday.

We sat at the table where Tesla incorporated. Of course.

He started out working on the Red Bull Formula 1 racing team, was an aerodynamics engineer. When Chat GPT first came along, he saw a new thing he could do for the team: analyze its petabytes of data in a new way. 

That got him to see the a new thing to do with data: help build robots.

So he built a network of people around the world who wear glasses with cameras on them and do tasks at home. Capture that task on video cameras on the glasses, like folding laundry. His dataset now has more than 10,000 hours of such video data. Which he sells to robot companies who are using it to build their world models. 

Almost every company on my robotics list who is located in USA or Europe buys his data. https://t.co/F3MplWNJEj

He told me he soon will have a pair of glasses that have nine cameras on them to collect even better data to train world models.

Shows how one person can dramatically change the world without being famous, or well known. But now you know. 

And he confirmed that World Models are changing robotics deeply and are the future. Among a few other things I'll keep to myself for now. After all, he knows the robotics industry deeper than anyone else I've met in my studying of the robotics industry.

He agrees that a generalized, humanoid robot, is years away. But when we all finally do get one it'll be his data that made it all happen. 

And he laid out some of the things he needs to build to help robots get trained on new things that are hard for them to learn from just video data. Brain/computer interfaces are in his head.

If I were to write another book about the future (I've already written eight), it would be about brain/computer interfaces and if I did write another book his work would be featured in the opening chapter. He is that important to the future, and it was an honor to spend a few hours with him.

items.title: It is always a cat and mouse game, one Google search and there's already sites that remove SynthID f...
items.content:
It is always a cat and mouse game, one Google search and there's already sites that remove SynthID for example

You can try regulate all you want, but you can't stop tech

A good example is Napster https://t.co/65PJhv4jlf

Napster allowed anyone to download and share music for free as MP3 files, that was groundbreaking for that time when you'd have to physically go to a record store to get a CD album and pay for it

Famously Metallica started suing people who downloaded their music, which was a bad idea, cause it was just fans, and it looked bad, and most of all it didn't work, nobody stopped download or sharing MP3s

Napster got shutdown but then people just switched to Kazaa, Limewire, Soulseek, and later Bittorrent

The only thing that made the file sharing technology exist in harmony again was Spotify (launched in 2006, and became dominant around 2018) which paid artists

My point is every new technology has a transitionary period where things get a bit wild and we're entering that now with AI, and trying to highly regulate or ban that is usually a bad idea

Imagine if we'd banned MP3 music files back then, we'd have never had Spotify which was literally just MP3 music files streamed but for a fee

Not really what you asked but yes

items.title: @arian_ghashghai I've been visiting robot companies in San Francisco and I agree with you: it is a v...
items.content:
@arian_ghashghai I've been visiting robot companies in San Francisco and I agree with you: it is a very tough business to make happen in the short term and even the long term. Tesla has so many advantages that it will be interesting to see who actually survives until world models are ready to power a generalized humanoid robot.

When I talk to people around the industry, almost everyone says that a generalized humanoid robot that is safe for homes is about five years away. Personally, I think it might be closer to three. I already bought a 1X Tech Neo robot for $20,000 that is coming this year, but that is hardly a generalized, all-AI robot yet. There is still a human embodied in the robot (teleoperation), and it will take a couple of years for them to finish the automation, partly through the training they get from early customers.

That said, there are a variety of different robotics companies taking different approaches and targeting different markets. It will be interesting to see which ones can get good enough to handle:
1. Factory work
2. Back-of-restaurant work

Getting into the home is a much tougher prospect. We have already seen a lot of robot companies come and go. Companies like Willow Garage, Giant Robot Company, and K-Scale are already gone; it is already an extinction event for them.

The next few years are going to be interesting. I have a list of everyone in robotics here on X if you want to follow that, and I am watching it very closely because I am highly interested in the field. I see a huge total addressable market with people who have mobility issues (there are about 60 million people in that situation) who could dramatically reduce their suffering if they had a robot.

The game is just starting. Internally, things have been cooking for a while, but nobody has a robot in their house yet, except for maybe Elon Musk‚Äîand even he doesn't really talk about these robots at home. Thanks!

items.title: I think there will be some regulation like you will have to disclose it's AI in a social media post ...
items.content:
I think there will be some regulation like you will have to disclose it's AI in a social media post or ad

And then on the human side social media platforms will start using biometrics to verify it's actually humans posting content

I don't think this stuff is going away though, the genie is out of the bottle and models like WAN can be run locally, so even if you try ban it all, you can't, and I think you shouldn't

Every new technology can be used for good and bad, society just adapts, in this case people have to become more critical of content they see to check if it's actually real or not

items.content: @DaveShapi I dunno, don't think it is that confusing: I gave it a joke name after Bladerunner, but the whole idea is  that you want to identify your sources of competitive advantage as a human, because if you just ask AI to do work that you add nothing to, there is no sustainable moat.

items.content_html: @DaveShapi I dunno, don't think it is that confusing: I gave it a joke name after Bladerunner, but the whole idea is that you want to identify your sources of competitive advantage as a human, because if you just ask AI to do work that you add nothing to, there is no sustainable moat.

items.title:
Me:

Past: Download PDF bank statements, copy and paste values into Excel, fill 12 sheets with reven...
items.content:
Me:

Past: Download PDF bank statements, copy and paste values into Excel, fill 12 sheets with revenues and expenses, create Excel formulas that sum everything, apply the tax rate to the final amount.

This year: Download PDF bank statements, paste them into Claude, ask it to write a script that parses these PDFs, fills 12 tabs, and applies rates, run the script, check if the numbers in the spreadsheet are in the right ranges.

Next year: Ask Claude to build a script that connects to the online bank account, downloads PDFs, parses them, and returns the tax amounts, check if the numbers in the spreadsheet are in the right ranges.

items.title: @miaw_330 Scientific proofs are also straightforward to convert into a reward number. The validation...
items.content:
@miaw_330 Scientific proofs are also straightforward to convert into a reward number. The validation of a proof can be automated by a script.

This should not be confused with doing scientific research because so far we don't have any evidence that the solutions found during reinforcement learning are entirely novel (not taken from the training data).
items.author: @burkov
items.summary: Burkov explaining that scientific proofs can be automated for RL rewards, but this shouldn't be confused with novel research as solutions may come from training data
items.reasoning: Technical nuance on RL capabilities vs. genuine scientific discovery
items.summary_html: Burkov explaining that scientific proofs can be automated for RL rewards, but this shouldn't be confused with novel research as solutions may come from training data
items.content_html:
@miaw_330 Scientific proofs are also straightforward to convert into a reward number. The validation of a proof can be automated by a script.

This should not be confused with doing scientific research because so far we don't have any evidence that the solutions found during reinforcement learning are entirely novel (not taken from the training data).

items.title: @arian_ghashghai Well, we're going to see Optimus 3 in April and then I'll see where we are. Maybe I...
items.content:
@arian_ghashghai Well, we're going to see Optimus 3 in April and then I'll see where we are. Maybe I'll change my point of view, but Tesla has 12,000 workers at the Fremont factory who are very willing to put cameras on their hands. I think they're going to have a significant announcement in April.

Either way, it doesn't matter. Figure hasn't really started up yet that much, and all the others haven't either. So even if they come in six months or a year late, they can just completely change the market because of their Robotaxi network (at least in places where there are a lot of Teslas).

items.title: Isabelle is a Director and Research Scientist at Google. She pioneered early applications of neural ...
items.content: Isabelle is a Director and Research Scientist at Google. She pioneered early applications of neural networks at AT&T Bell Labs in the 1990's, and co-invented SVMs. She has been action editor at JMLR for 20 years and was the program chair of NIPS 2016.

items.title: @OfirSela @bercankilic Oh, believe me, the robot companies aren't only doing video models to run the...
items.author: @Scobleizer
items.summary: Explains robot AI infrastructure is more complex than just video models - includes sim-to-real transfer, path planning, and real-world manipulation
items.reasoning: Technical insight into robotics AI development complexity from someone visiting robot companies
items.summary_html: Explains robot AI infrastructure is more complex than just video models - includes sim-to-real transfer, path planning, and real-world manipulation
items.content_html:
@OfirSela @bercankilic Oh, believe me, the robot companies aren't only doing video models to run the robots. There's a whole AI infrastructure to build the software that gets loaded into the robots.

You're absolutely right that they need to worry about the sim-to-real transfer and making sure that everything, particularly path planning and manipulation of the real world, is done properly.

All of that is way over my head, but I see the work that's going on inside the robot companies, and it goes far beyond just collecting videos and sticking them into NVIDIA cards.

items.title: @arian_ghashghai Well, I've seen all the Chinese robots. I went to CES and saw them again, and they'...
items.author: @Scobleizer
items.summary: Analysis of Chinese robots at CES - not ready for homes, expensive ($50-100K), but Americans have better AI while China has better manufacturing
items.reasoning: First-hand CES observation, insightful comparison of US vs China AI/manufacturing capabilities
items.summary_html: Analysis of Chinese robots at CES - not ready for homes, expensive ($50-100K), but Americans have better AI while China has better manufacturing
items.content_html:
@arian_ghashghai Well, I've seen all the Chinese robots. I went to CES and saw them again, and they're not ready to get into people's homes either. They are not very smart, they're not very capable, and the ones that are pretending to be capable and smart are going to be very expensive.

The Sharps hands (for instance, that you saw dealing cards and playing ping pong) cost about $50,000 to $100,000. That's way too expensive to get into anybody's homes, and that's the kind of technology you're going to need to get into people's homes.

So, I'm not as worried about China as I once was. You know the Chinese are going to be able to make things at scale really quick, but the Americans have better AI. I can see a whole reason not to allow Chinese software into your country, because if you do, you're going to be enslaving your country to China.

You get a certain amount of points at start of year, then every bad traffic thing you do gets a point removed, and/or you get fined I think

You can even buy points of other people and transfer them to you

At end of year it resets

items.title: @LexSokolin @arian_ghashghai @TheHumanoidAI From what I see, that's a mounted robot that is great fo...
items.author: @Scobleizer
items.summary: Scobleizer discusses humanoid robots vs mounted robots, emphasizing versatility of walking humanoids
items.reasoning: Analytical comparison of robot form factors and use cases
items.summary_html: Scobleizer discusses humanoid robots vs mounted robots, emphasizing versatility of walking humanoids
items.content_html:
@LexSokolin @arian_ghashghai @TheHumanoidAI From what I see, that's a mounted robot that is great for a single task or a small number of tasks. It's not going to be a generalized robot that can walk around the factory and do hundreds of different tasks, which is what a walking humanoid robot can do.

It also isn't at the place where you can have it in somebody's home.

But why do you ask the question? What do you see that I'm missing?

items.title: It's pathetic that these folks come to Elon's social network to complain about Elon. And it's double...
items.content:
It's pathetic that these folks come to Elon's social network to complain about Elon. And it's double pathetic to say that someone is dishonest but still profit from this dishonest person's public reach.

There are a couple of folks here who always accuse Elon of manipulating X's post visibility, shadowbanning those who criticize him. These folks about once a quarter say that they are leaving this crooked place, but they are back after just a week or so on LinkedIn or some hole like Threads or Bluesky.

I'm not sure I would be as forgiving and neutral to those who come to my house and shit in the living room.

items.title: @WR4NYGov @arian_ghashghai That is exactly why the rental model will work so well. If I only need it...
items.content:
@WR4NYGov @arian_ghashghai That is exactly why the rental model will work so well. If I only need it for four hours to do my laundry, I can rent it and then put it back in the network so it can go and work somewhere else.

That model makes a lot more sense to me than paying $500 a month for a robot.

items.title: @erildox There's going to be more demand than they can satisfy for years, at least. And so, it makes...
items.author: @Scobleizer
items.summary: Discusses resource sharing model for robots - plans to rent his 1X Tech Neo robot to neighbors and build a business around it
items.reasoning: Part of ongoing thread, personal example of robot rental business model
items.summary_html: Discusses resource sharing model for robots - plans to rent his 1X Tech Neo robot to neighbors and build a business around it
items.content_html:
@erildox There's going to be more demand than they can satisfy for years, at least. And so, it makes sense to force everyone to optimize their usage of the resource by renting it.

If you want to rent it and put it in your garage, that's on you. But most people, when they rent something, they're going to use it, and they're only going to rent something if they have a need. It just makes sense to share a resource amongst the community and rent it out. Even with the Neo robot that's coming this year, I'm going to rent it out to my neighbors and build a little business around it.

The only question is: does Elon want the customers to fund that capability, or does he want to own everything? I can see a business reason to only rent.

items.title: @WR4NYGov @arian_ghashghai Totally agreed! They have the money to pay for them, but the home user is...
items.content:
@WR4NYGov @arian_ghashghai Totally agreed! They have the money to pay for them, but the home user is going to struggle to see why they need a $20,000 robot in their home.

There just aren't that many tasks in the average home:
1. Laundry
2. Cooking
3. Dishes

How much is that worth? There are people who pay a couple hundred bucks a month to have cleaners come in and clean their homes, but that's hardly enough to pay for a $20,000 robot.

items.title: @BenandAurora @tslaming I'm writing you from my Hardware 3 car in the fast lane on Highway 101 in Si...
items.author: @Scobleizer
items.summary: Praises Tesla FSD updates on Hardware 3, wishes for Hardware 4 upgrade, notes early customers helped train models
items.reasoning: Perspective on Tesla FSD development and hardware evolution
items.summary_html: Praises Tesla FSD updates on Hardware 3, wishes for Hardware 4 upgrade, notes early customers helped train models
items.content_html:
@BenandAurora @tslaming I'm writing you from my Hardware 3 car in the fast lane on Highway 101 in Silicon Valley. To all the haters: this stuff is magic! What is all the angst about?

I personally think Tesla has done enough, though that will probably piss everybody off. I am loving the latest updates, and I think we have a little bit more to squeeze out of Hardware 3 before they completely give up on it.

I sure would love to get a Hardware 4 computer in my car to help with my computer speed. I think the old customers deserve a little bit of extra care because we helped train the models that are going to give Tesla a competitive edge in the world.

‚Äî‚Äî
Grok says: Grafana is an open-source platform for monitoring, visualization, and observability. It allows users to create, explore, and share dashboards with data from various sources like databases, cloud services, and monitoring tools (e.g., Prometheus, InfluxDB, Elasticsearch). Grafana is widely used for visualizing time-series data, such as server metrics, application performance, or IoT sensor data, through customizable charts, graphs, and alerts. It supports plugins for extensibility and is popular in DevOps and IT for real-time system monitoring and analytics.

items.title: @lalopenguin @BrianRoemmele I have one of the first 10,000 made and it has a leather steering wheel,...
items.content:
@lalopenguin @BrianRoemmele I have one of the first 10,000 made and it has a leather steering wheel, and I'm not giving it up. I'm on Highway 101 right now in my eight-year-old robot and I love it. It's better than any other car that you can probably buy today, unless it's a Tesla. 

We also have a new Model Y and, yep, that is better. It's:
1. Quieter
2. Smoother
3. Faster
4. Equipped with a better computer
items.author: @Scobleizer
items.summary: Personal anecdote about owning early Model 3 with leather steering wheel, comparing to new Model Y improvements
items.reasoning: Personal ownership story, tangentially related to AI/autonomy
items.summary_html: Personal anecdote about owning early Model 3 with leather steering wheel, comparing to new Model Y improvements

items.title: Whenever you see what #ICE is doing in front of cameras, you must imagine what they're doing whe...
items.content: Whenever you see what #ICE is doing in front of cameras, you must imagine what they're doing where nobody can see them--like in the concentration camps the USA is building. It's easy to read those words and much harder to fathom what they mean; that this is happening in our day and age, in what until recently was believed to be a first world country. "Abolish ICE" doesn't go nearly far enough in my view.
items.author: @Gargron@mastodon.social
items.summary: Eugen Rochko posts political commentary about ICE detention practices
